Quick Reference: Wound Types & Dressings

Key Principles:

  • Assess the Wound: Consider characteristics like drainage, tissue type (eschar, slough, granulation), depth, and infection.
  • Determine Goals: Decide if debridement, infection control, or healing promotion is the priority.
  • Consult Wound Care: Collaborate with wound care specialists, especially for complex or changing wounds.
  • Verify Orders: Follow wound care orders and use nursing judgment when needed.
  • Monitor for Complications: Watch for infection, skin reactions, and dressing-related issues.

Wound Types & Recommended Dressings:

  • Superficial Wounds:
    • Films, PMDs (Polymeric Membrane Dressings)
  • Wounds with Eschar (Thick, Dead Tissue):
    • Hydrogels, Hydrocolloids, PMDs
  • Wounds with Exudate (Drainage):
    • Alginates, Hydrofibers, Foams (use with caution), PMDs
  • Granulating Wounds (Healing):
    • Hydrocolloids, Hydrogels, PMDs
  • Wounds with Slough (Loose, Dead Tissue):
    • Hydrogels, Hydrocolloids, Wet-to-dry dressings
  • Deep Wounds:
    • Alginates, Hydrofibers, Hydrocolloids, PMDs (often with packing)
  • Infected Wounds:
    • Antimicrobial dressings (silver, iodine-impregnated)

Dressing Types:

  • Films: Thin, transparent, for superficial wounds.
  • PMDs (Polymeric Membrane Dressings): Versatile, used for various wound types.
  • Hydrogels: Add moisture, for dry wounds and debridement.
  • Hydrocolloids: Absorb moisture, for moderate drainage and debridement.
  • Alginates: Highly absorbent, for heavy drainage.
  • Hydrofibers: Highly absorbent, for heavy drainage and deep wounds.
  • Foams: Absorbent, for moderate to heavy drainage (use with caution).
  • Wet-to-Dry Dressings: For debridement.
  • Antimicrobial Dressings: Prevent and treat infection.
